description: Party game. 16 cards are placed around the room where they can all be seen by the guests. Each card has a rhyming clue to a place. Guests taking part write down their answers and the one with the most correct when the host calls "Time", wins.

Ziege mit Fliege is a memory card game for children.

By turn, cards are placed face down on different piles.
This cards show either a colour, an animal, a piece of clothing or an activity.
4 different cards make one pile. Players have to remember this cards and make a sentence out of this cars, "A green beavers is skateboarding in a diving suit" for example.

Top This! is a fun-filled, strategic board game of pizza making for 2 to 5 players. Manage your toppings and flick them skillfully to win!

Players take turns flicking wooden "pizza topping" pieces onto a pizza-like game board. Their goal is to position toppings so as to fulfill orders precisely, while managing their inventory of toppings. Players can earn tips by showing off (by yelling "Top This!" before flicking a topping) or by fulfilling two orders in one turn. The winner is the player with the most money (from orders and tips).

From the game publisher's web site:

"RoShamBo (aka Rock Paper Scissors) is a board game that takes an age-old concept and transforms it into a game like no other on the market — ever. Ro Sham Bo is simple yet complex — an entertaining game that makes play fast, intense, and sometimes personal, but most of all fun.

It's pretty simple (but for those of you who have been living under a rock — no pun intended…) Rock beats scissors, scissors beats paper, paper beats rock. Got it so far?

Players advance toward the winner's level by rolling the dice or by winning challenges.

However, more is at stake than just winning the game (on the board) — challenges can go beyond traditional game play.

Along the way players land on spaces that call for challenges that range from moving ahead a few spaces and changing places with the winner, to being everyone's butler for the rest of the game, or doing a crazy stunt or challenge of the cardholder's choice.

Mad Science The Card Game is a family friendly game played in three phases. Players must first construct a creature from bodies and parts. then they battle the Horrible Experiment created by  Dr. Emil Knutberger to save the city. Finally, they fight each other, knocking off parts until only one creation remains standing.

Phase One is purely cards while Phases Two and Three also make use of a D6.

The core set works best with 2 or 3 players. Expansion sets allow for up to 6 players. There is also a Phase Two Solitary version of play.

There are questions about horses, the breeds, husbandry and care, training of horse and rider about the equestrian sport. Question and 3 answer choices on each card. 
Answer correctly and move Your pawn on the game board.
Who finishes first is the winner.

62 multiple questions about the categories of art and media, Peaceful Revolution, everyday life and leisure, politics, history etc. about former East-Germany

In player's turn his left neighbor reads aloud a question. 
If the answer is correct he receives one point and answers another question. Otherwise, the next player has a turn. The winner is whoever has accumulated the most points at the end of the game.

UNAUTHORIZED PRODUCTION

    
    
         The information that BGG has on this item indicates that Block City is a non-authorized version of Quoridor.

    


In this game, players are trying to move a pawn from one side of the board to the other.  Each turn a player may move a pawn one space, and can add a wall piece to the board that blocks the progress between play areas.  The winner of the game is the one that can first move his piece across the opponent's border.

Ditsö is a strategy game of skirmish battles for all the family, that shows native Costa Rican mythology, language, customs and traditions.

The game recreates the fight among gods and other magical beings to take over Tisingal, the place where, according to the legend, lay the lost gold mines of Talamanca.

With Ditsö the player get used to the Bri Bri language and learns about the importance of some symbols of great value for our ancestors, like the fact that Sibö is the creator according to the Bri Bri, Cabécar and Brunca mythologies,or the meaning of fur or feathers for the indigenous warriors.

The name of the game itself was thinked with this purpose. Ditsö means "group" or "clan", which is represented by character cards that each player chooses to form his/her tribe. Each card has an explanation about what each character means in the native mythology, and the locations and unique figures keep their indigenous names.

In terms of gameplay, Ditsö is played like a miniatures game, althoough it uses cards (folded in the middle so they can stand) instead of miniatures. Each player or team has a certain amount of points (100 points in a standard game) to recruit an army; each card has a value. It is allowed to recruit as many green cards of the same type as whished, but only one golden card of the same kind may be recruited.

Then players set their armies in the predesignated start zones and the game begins. Depending of the charactes chosen, they may have special abilities, but normally the options will be to start a melee combat, a ranged combat or just to move (some characters have the ability of flying). There is also the chance to counter attack, but the character should have this ability to do so.

The first player of team to destroy his/her opponent wins the game.

Ditsö won the 2011 Ideas Innovadoras Award in the social innovation cathegory, and is an attempt to rescue Costa Rican roots in a fun and familiar way.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Braunschweig. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Weimar. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German district of Harz. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German town of Freiburg. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Münster. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German Football club of Fortuna Düsseldorf. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

In this learning game for 3-6 players aged 5 and up children can improve observation and miming play skills.

One by one, in a clockwise direction the players draws a card and represent the animal on the card. All other players try to guess which animal is meant.

Whoever scores the biggest amount of points by both acting and guessing animals, wins the game

Action game where the object is to score 'hoops'.

The board is enclosed and has a 'shooter' at the bottom right and a basketball hoop just above middle centre. The shooter is spring-loaded so that, when you pull it back and let go, it will launch a ball at the top of the board with the aim of getting it to drop into the basket. Most hoops, wins.

The game is a derivative of Bagatelle but is also quite different as it only has one scoring target (the basket).

In Mice and Mystics, players take on the roles of those still loyal to the king – but to escape the clutches of Vanestra, they have been turned into mice! Play as cunning field mice who must race through a castle now twenty times larger than before. The castle would be a dangerous place with Vanestra's minions in control, but now countless other terrors also await heroes who are but the size of figs. Play as nimble Prince Collin and fence your way past your foes, or try Nez Bellows, the burly smith. Confound your foes as the wizened old mouse Maginos, or protect your companions as Tilda, the castle's former healer. Every player will have a vital role in the quest to warn the king, and it will take careful planning to find Vanestra's weakness and defeat her.

Mice and Mystics is a cooperative adventure game in which the players work together to save an imperiled kingdom. They will face countless adversaries such as rats, cockroaches, and spiders, and of course the greatest of all horrors: the castle's housecat, Brodie. Mice and Mystics is a boldly innovative game that thrusts players into an ever-changing, interactive environment, and features a rich storyline that the players help create as they play the game. The Cheese System allows players to hoard the crumbs of precious cheese they find on their journey, and use it to bolster their mice with grandiose new abilities and overcome seemingly insurmountable odds.

Mice and Mystics will provide any group of friends with an unforgettable adventure they will be talking about for years to come – assuming they can all squeak by...



Expansion advice:

For those who have expansions for this game the recommended order by the game designer for playing them is as follows (see original post HERE):

        Sorrow and Remembrance (Base game)
        Cat's Cradle (Lost Chapter 1)
        Heart of Glorm
        The Ghost of Castle Andon (Lost Chapter 2)
        Downwood Tales
        Portents of Importance (Lost Chapter 3), connected to the story in Tail Feathers

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German state of Schleswig-Holstein. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Wiesbaden. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Hildesheim. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the lake of Bodensee situated in Germany, Switzerland and Austria near the Alps. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Bonn. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German city of Augsburg. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Simple trivia game with questions related to the German former state of Württemberg. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

You can play with the famous 'Chat' (by cartoonist Philippe Geluck) through a game that includes 560 drawings and 600 tasks!

This is a game full of humour and surprises for all the family!

Tasks include drawing, questions, mimics, guesses and observations.  Players moves their respective pawns on something similar to 'snake and ladders', the landing square indicating what task to perform.  The player wins by landing on the final square.

Trivia card game about German region of Bavaria. There are questions about culture and media, politics and current affairs, business and science, history, life and leisure, and geography.

In player' turn his left neighbor reads aloud a question. 
If he answer correclty he receives one point and must answer another question. Otherwise, the next player has a turn. The winner is whoever has accumulated the most points at the end.

Trivia game about Germany. Questions about culture, economics, history and politics.

In player's turn his left neighbor reads aloud a question. 
If he answer correctly he receives one point and must answer another question. Otherwise, the next player has a turn. The winner is whoever has accumulated the most points at the end.

Trivia game about Europe. 62 multiple questions about geography, politics, culture, history, institutions, and records.

In player's turn his left neighbor reads aloud a question. 
If he answer corretly he receives one point and must answer another question. Otherwise, the next player has a turn. The winner is whoever has accumulated the most points at the end.

The hollow sound as the ball strikes the court, the exhilaration as you draw your racquet back, the roar of the crowd as you deliver that forehand smash you’ve been training for your entire life... Do you have what it takes to be a famous tennis player? Find out today with Famous Forehand - the World's Smallest Tennis Game!


Famous Forehand is a fun, fast-playing simulation of the sport of tennis. The game focuses on positional play, with each player receiving four randomly dealt cards prior to every serve. Each card depicts two key positions that you’re able reach on your half of the course and the paths along which you’ll be returning the ball. A penny tracks the position of the the tennis ball throughout the rally. The first player who’s unable to return the ball loses the point. Famous Forehand is Game #2 in the Famous Games Company's line of Worldâ€™s Smallest Sports Games and the most accessible of the game designs.

The feel of the laces against your fingers, the catch in your throat as the pocket closes in, the confidence as you unload that your wideout will be there... Do you have what it takes to be a famous football player? Find out today with  Famous First Downs - the World's Smallest Gridiron Football Game!


Famous First Downs is a fun, fast-playing simulation of the sport of American football. The game focuses on offensive and defensive play-calling and on the need to build and manage your team’s momentum over multiple scoring drives. Each down, the offense declares a play to which the defense secretly responds. The offense then chooses a play option, resulting in the success or failure of the play and determining any subsequent yardage. Blocked plays earn momentum for the defense while first downs earn momentum for the offense. That momentum can then be spent on special plays like interceptions, extra yards, and repeated downs. The various coins are used to track downs, momentum, and yardage. Famous First Downs is the fourth game in the Famous Games Company's line of Worldâ€™s Smallest Sports Games and a personal favourite of the company's founder.

THROWDOWN! is a turn based card game that uses the Draw-Attack-Discard system or D.A.D.s. During the game you will have a character, a deck, and a discard pile. First you need at least 2 or more people to play and each person will need to have their own character card (a Robot, a Cowboy, or a Samurai), and deck, (the deck contains only 50 cards and is full of attacks, equipment, and modifiers). The objective of the game is to attack your opponents deck. You do this with your character card and cards you draw from your deck. You win when their deck is completely depleted. No matter how many people play you will always attack the person to your left, so until you get down to two players you cannot attack the person that attacked you.

Setting up to play is easy just place your character card next to your deck and your discard pile will go on the other side of your character. Flip a coin to see who goes first, then follow 3 easy steps. STEP 1 DRAW - On your turn DRAW a card from your deck and place it in front of your character card. STEP 2 ATTACK - Your character must ATTACK on your turn and will automatically defend your deck on your opponents turn. Total and resolve conflict damage. Follow any additional rules on the card. STEP 3 DISCARD - Now discard the card in play and put it into your discard pile, it is now your opponents turn and they follow the 3 easy steps.

The players race against Eric, leader of the "Wölfe von Ragnarök", to be first at the gate af Ragnarök.
On their turn a player chooses how many dice rolls he wants to perform. Than he rolls the die that many times and moves his pawn forward. If he rolls the X the players turn is over and Eric moves the number of spaces the player chose to roll his die.
The player who reaches the gate first befor Eric does wins the game. If Eric reaches the gate first, all players lose.

Long before the threat of the Nemesis, before the perils of warp drive or the founding of our own Space Academy, humanity experienced a Golden Age of space exploration. The mineral riches of the thriving Moon colony inspired legions of hearty Earth citizens to seek their fortunes in space. Humble rockets probed the farthest reaches of the solar system in an eager quest for resources, and brave colonists forged homes wherever they could survive. Pioneer life was hard, but the men and women who worked and raised their families on those planets and asteroids had much to be proud of.

Then the rumors began — whispered tales of frontier abductions and sightings of mysterious creatures. By the time the secret invasion was exposed, the aliens were everywhere. Families had been stolen away by slavers from the stars, and the peace-loving survivors had no choice but to arm themselves and fight. Fight to stop the alien attacks! Fight to free the helpless abductees! Fight to throw the aggressors back into space and end forever their power to threaten humanity!

Thus was born the Rocket Patrol – an organization of brave and hearty women and men dedicated to defending humanity and taking the fight to the alien menace from the stars.

Space Cadets: Away Missions is a cooperative, scenario-based, tactical action game for 1-6 players, which is set in the Golden Age of science fiction. In this game, the third standalone title in the Space Cadets franchise of cooperative/team space-themed games from Stronghold Games, players take on the roles of adventurous human spacemen who explore UFOs, acquire Alien technology and fight hostile extraterrestrials.

Each turn, spacemen have three action points to spend on activities such as firing their atomic rifles, analyzing exotic equipment, or subduing the malicious Brain-in-a-Jar. When the spacemen are finished, the aliens take their turns by following simple movement and combat protocols; seven types of hostile aliens threaten the players, from the repulsive mind leeches to the rampaging titanic sentinels.

Space Cadets: Away Missions contains twenty scenarios linked in a campaign story. Each mission features different combinations of aliens on different spaceships, with hexagonal map tiles arranged to form flying saucers, rocket ships, space stations, etc. Cooperation, tactical planning and good dice are essential if the spacemen hope to overcome the relentless horde of little green men.

Tentacle Bento is a cheeky, fast-playing trick-taking card game for 2 to 4 players. Each game puts you in the enviable position of being a horrid, tentacle-flailing, slime-oozing monster from outer space – cleverly disguised (of course) as an adorable and newly enrolled student at Takoashi University, an all-girls school nestled in scenic Japan.

Play requires matching a student, a location, and an action in order to get points for that student. Any suit combination of these cards is sufficient for a "sloppy capture", but a "noble capture" (all items of the same suit) allows you to capture up to three students simultaneously. Noble captures also allow additional game actions.

Suits in the game are "cute", "sexy", "sporty", and "smart". Cultural events (such as Sports Day) and special personalities can also modify the basic game play.

"Maurice" is a delightful combination of tabletop miniatures rules for historical and fictional battles, a limitless campaign system that requires virtually no math or paperwork, and a role-playing game in which the “characters” are officers, units, and armies, whose personalities you create, and whose fates you manage from battle to battle across wars and decades.

The game play is driven by the action cards, which are used to activate forces and to modify those actions. Each card has the potential to do more than one thing, but can only ever be used for a single thing at any given time. The game is played in alternating rounds. The active player first chooses whether or not volleys will be fired by both sides. Then he decides whether to play a card for its event, or activate a group of units to march, rally, charge, or bombard. To activate a force a number of cards need to be discarded for their "span" number based on the distance from the commander to the force. The action also determines how many new cards may be drawn, the more vigorous action the fewer cards. Or he could also choose to pass and draw more cards. A group of units depends on their physical proximity, type, and formation. An additional card may be played to modify an action. The passive player might have interrupt cards that enable him to inject complications into the 
active player’s action. The game continues until one side’s army morale breaks. If neither side’s army morale breaks before the game runs out of cards, then night has fallen without a decisive victory.

A card-laying game with verbs based on the well-known Mau-Mau game. A card can be played when it shows either the same person with another activity as on the face-up card or another person with the same activity.

The first player who can put all their cards down wins the game.

An old style game. Players build their wealth by speculating on stock exchange, takes loan, investing in knowledge, expliot chances of life (means events).

Mechanic is standard -I go you go -.  Interaction is  little. Resources to buy are plentful and players really don't have to compete with each other.

Purpose of game is to collect the most wealth.

A game with lot of banking and 'economy' mechanics. 
A loose adaptation of Monopoly in science fiction climate of future humanity - we have similar buying system and board to Monopoly.
Edition of this project was limited.

In 1911, Roald Amundsen and four companions were the first human beings to stand at the South Pole. Using skis and dog sleds, they beat Robert Falcon Scott's British expedition by just a few weeks. Scott and his men reached the South Pole only to find Amundsen's Norwegian flag planted in the frozen ground. They died on their return journey not far from their base camp.

1911 Amundsen vs Scott is an asymmetric game for two players, with both of them trying to be the first to reach the South Pole. Each player takes a different route to the South Pole, with these routes consisting of a path of colored dots.

The game is composed by a deck of cards for both players with a row of 3 visible cards. On each turn a player can:


     Collect cards that are face up on the board, taking one card for free, or taking 2-3 cards by first discarding 1-2 cards from your hand.
     Play cards from his hand to advance toward the South Pole, play cards so that the opponent loses his way, or play cards to activate special effects.


The first player to reach the South Pole wins. If the deck runs out for the second time, both players are lost in Antarctica and lose the game.

This game includes 4 expansions inside:
- "Patrons" (8 new cards). 4 British patrons and 4 Norwegian patrons with a special effect each.
- "1912 The Way Back" (second board + 10 new cards). The explorers can play the return to the ships with new rules.
- "Damned Weather!" (5 new cards + 1 die). A small expansion to represent the influence of weather and add a little bit of gambling to the game.
- "Food Depots" (4 white cubes). Only in the second edition!. The explorers made previous short trips to create food depots that they could pick up in the final trip.

Horse lovers will enjoy the view of their favorite animal while playing the Hooray for Horses Card Game. A great game for horse lovers, the Hooray for Horses Card Game includes thick and large cards that are perfect for growing card players. The Hooray for Horses Card Game includes 48 colorful game cards with instructions to play 5 games:

1) Hooray for Horses - In this game, whoever is the first person to get rid of all his/her cards shouts "no more horses" and is the winner.

2) No More Horses! - The object of this game is to match the horses shown on the cards and to win the most pairs.  When one of the players uses up all his/her cards, or when there are no cards left in the deck, the game ends and points are calculated.

3) Color Rummy - You have to be the first player to colelct 5 cards of the same color.

4) Classic Rummy - The object is to be the first player to match all the cards in his/her hand by collecting 3 cards picturing one horse and 4 cards picturing another.

5) Horse Memory - You have to collect the most pairs.  As the game is played, players claim matches until all the cards are claimed.  Whoever has the most matching pairs is the winner.

The beautifully detailed illustrations on these playing cards depict breeds of breathtaking horses to help kids identify and name each type of horse. The Hooray for Horses Card Game is the perfect game for horse lovers and card players alike!

Dastardly Virxles have invaded the mainframe and are running amuck.  You, as a system administrator, must load your program into a detonation node and set off chain reactions, scoring points for how many you get.  The chaining system can lead to massive scores and ultimate victory.

At the beginning of the game, players select which Virxle (color) they are going after and set up an initial board.  Then, on their turn, they can play a card (Special Program or Circuit Card), load a program (placing a token on a detonation node), or run a program (setting off the program and scoring Virxles in your path).  Circuit Cards contain Virxles and detonation points, which players put down, building the board as they play. When running a program, the detonation node has a set distance (in one of the cardinal directions) the explosion travels.  If it can reach another detonation point, a chain begins and can continue for up to 9 detonations points.  Bonus points are scored for longer chains.

More advanced rules variants introduce Virxles the player must avoid as they become negative points.

In essence, Lilly Frog is a 4-in-a-row game for two players. The game is played on a 6x6 checkered board. The pattern consists of green water lilly leaves and purple lotus flowers. The playing pieces (6 per player) are cutely crafted wooden frogs in the same colors.

In the initial set-up 3 frogs per player are standing on both baselines; green frogs start on the green leaves, purple frogs on the purple flowers.

A turn consists of moving a frog of the own player color to an adjacent, free space. The color of the spaces doesn't matter any more at this point. The first player to get 4 frogs in a row, wins the game.

A game variant with hopping frogs allows for a faster game.

Lilly Frog is part of the same series as ChessQuito of the same editor.

An educational game designed to demonstrate how health care costs work in the U.S. health care system.

Players roll and move around a circular track, paying and receiving money as directed on the squares they land on, or on "Cost" cards drawn when they land on a "Cost" square.
Each player has a varying Salary, which determines how much money they receive when they land on Collect Your Income squares; and a varying Insurance Status (Uninsured, Underinsured or Insured), which affects how much they have to pay on "Cost" squares.

When a player runs out of money they are in "Limbo" and take no further part in the game.  The last player surviving outside "Limbo" is the winner.

Tit 3 Tat is game #30 of the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

Tit 3 Tat is a 3 player only game on half a checkerboard, with each player having 6 pieces of their color.  In the game, players attempt to control more spaces on the board by the time the game ends.  Pieces move like chess queens, and have the ability to pass through spaces control by their side.  Each turn, a player must either move one of their pieces on top of a single piece of an opponent, or remove an enemy piece on top of a stack from two players (this is in the basic version, with a variant providing more complex removal rules). Effort was made to provide a 3 player game experience that would try to prevent players from colluding to gang up against a single player in order to eliminate them from play.

The game provides a unique feature where it is possible for a player to win a game, even if they haven't made a move.  In addition, turn order is not fixed, and depends totally on who a player interacts with during their turn.

Swordfish is a German game on the fishing and the commerce of swordfish. Close to the North Atlantic continental shelf is a group of shallow underwater plateaus called Grand Banks. This area is unique because the cold Labrador Current mixes with the warm waters of the Gulf Stream. The mixing of the streams and the shape of the ocean bottom lifts nutrients to the surface, helping to create one of the richest fishing grounds in the world – but it is also the cause of violent storms that happen in the best fishing zone of this area: the well-known Flemish Cap of The Perfect Storm.

The players will have to manage their victory points when they are on the coast to hire boats, engage captains and crews, and buy the proper quantities of fuel and bait so as to sail the Ocean at their best and fish the heaviest and most profitable swordfish of the world.

Only the most skilled and bravest seamen will be able to take to the open sea without fear through the storm, find the "triple markers", and sell the catch in order to have the most victory points at the end of the season.

Who Took the Apple? is a cardgame played backwards in time.

The goal of the game is to take an apple which is placed under a bucket. Players "pre program" their actions, like in Space Alert or Roborally, but cards are played backwards in time: First card played will be last action happening.

In the second phase of the game, all players go through their actions to resolve what actually happened. Some actions might be impossible to carry out which creates a paradox. These cards are ignored in order to restore space/time logic. Players have to maintain multiple possible game states in their head in order to successfully play.

Up to four princesses try to reach the Magic Castle first to open the big ball. The active player waves the (electronic) magic wand which then gives instructions about movement (mostly letting the princess move forward, but sometimes doing spells which change the path to the castle, let a princess swap places with another princess, etc. Some fields protect the princess from spells, other yield a diamond that can neutralize spells. The first princess to reach the castle is the winner.

You are the Red Joker. Find and kill your evil twin, the Black Joker.

Players layout number cards to represent Rooms, Doors, and Levels, battle Jacks, Kings, and Queens with hit points,search for the Black Joker through up to ten levels in an ever changing maze dealt with a simple deck of standard playing cards. A Quick reference book lays out the mechanisms for movement, combat, Hand-management, and for finding and fighting the Black Joker.

“All my life I’ve known my brother was the evil twin. I’ve always felt that one of us shouldn’t have been born. Today, one of us dies in Blackie’s Maze.”

In the cooking-themed card game Raid the Pantry, for 2-4 individuals or two teams of two, players are dealt ingredient and dish cards at the start of play; over the course of the game, players need to collect the ingredients needed to make the dishes in hand. Each completed dish scores you 1-3 points, locks in its ingredients for reuse in other dishes, and allows you to take a new dish card. Action cards, drawn at the beginning of a turn, provide ways to add, lose, trade and retrieve ingredient cards. The eight "Instant Dishes" among the action cards allow players to lock in a common ingredient and score 1 point.
  
Players can score a "cuisine bonus" for making multiple dishes from one of the five primary cuisines featured on dish cards (American, Continental, French, Italian and Mexican). The first player to reach a point threshold, which depends on the number of players, wins.

In the team version, players end the round and total their points when the Action card deck has been exhausted.

Raid the Pantry is the winner of the New Zealand New Game of the Year 2013 award from the New Zealand Games Association.  It also won a Game of the Year 2013 award from Creative Child Magazine and one of first ever "Recommended by American Mensa" commendations.

Originally published by SchilMil Games in May 2012, Cheeky Parrot Games acquired the title in 2014 and released a second edition, with some graphical and gameplay tweaks, in June 2015.

The Drinking Roulette contains 16 glasses for vodka which have their place around the roulette. Some of the glasses should be filled with vodka, some with water. Players bet red or black and those players who bet correctly drink one glass of vodka or water (they don't know). If a player bet 0 and guess, he/she drinks all the glasses. After drinking each player is allowed to leave the game. The last player in the game is declared the winner.
